awd_titl_txt: The Long-Term and Intergenerational Effects of Fertility Policies
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will examine the long term and intergenerational impact of policies in the 1970s and 1980s to reduce teen pregnancy. We analyze the effects of interventions that were designed to influence the likelihood of teen pregnancy. These interventions were adopted by various municipalities and affected women of different ages in different locations, creating a quasi-experiment.

Previous studies have produced convincing evidence that young women who have better control over family planning make different career and lifelong fertility choices. However, we know little about the potential long-term effects of these career and childbearing decisions on the children born to these women. Identifying the short- and the long-term effects of the social mechanisms at work - women's fertility and career decisions and the impact on their children - is at the core of the intellectual merit of the proposal.

This work uses individual-level registry data on the health, education, and labor market outcomes of three generations of Swedes to trace out the effect of these family planning policies on the short-, medium-, and long-term health and socio-economic outcomes of the affected women and their children. Swedish registry data link parents to children across generations, allowing the PIs to compare sisters, who were affected by the policies to those who were not, and their children.

Understanding the impact of health care policies on women's and children's health and social well-being is important for predicting the costs and benefits of a wide range of policies.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project is to identify the short- and long-term effects of reducing barriers to access to contraceptive technologies on the affected women and their children’s long-term outcomes, with a particular focus on the social and economic mechanisms at work, such as women’s fertility choices and career decisions as well as their ability to secure a higher quality partner.  Different mechanisms may have substantially different implications for social policies, yet currently we only have a broad sense of the average effects on some demographic groups of legalizing contraceptives use in the United States. Furthermore, there may be significant differences in the impacts of such policies on women of differing socio-economic backgrounds, yet assessing these differences is not possible in the absence of information on the family backgrounds of affected women. This work has built a unique dataset based on individual-level registry data on the health, education, and labor market outcomes of three generations of Swedes, which enables an in-depth examination of how the effects of such policies may differ across demographic and socio-economic groups. The empirical analysis exploits the implementation of different-sized subsidies for oral contraceptives (the pill) in various municipalities in Sweden during the 1990s as a social experiment. Because the subsidies were aimed at women of different ages across municipalities, we are able to exploit differences in subsidy treatment across women from the same birth cohorts at the same calendar time. The investigation has revealed several important findings. First, lowering the cost of oral contraceptives increases the consumption of oral contraceptives and lowers the rates of pregnancy termination among women of subsidy-eligible ages. Second, the average age at first childbearing increases for those affected by the subsidies, however total fertility per woman does not differ, as more children are born later in life. Third, subsidy-eligible women are more likely to enroll in educational programs after completing high school. Fourth, grades and test scores for the children of these women are higher than those for children of similar women who were not eligible for lower contraceptive costs. Finally, all of these effects are more pronounced among women from less educated families. Overall, the results suggest that lowering the barriers to contraceptive technologies has positive effects on the long-term outcomes for women and their children and likely help break the intergenerational transmission of low socio-economic status.

 

The study has resulted in collaborations across disciplines between economists and public health and medical researchers. As of the year 2017, it has influenced the public policy debate in Sweden, cited in a parliamentary bill advocating contraceptive subsidies, and impacted ongoing work to reduce teen pregnancies in Thailand.
